questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following epithelia does not line the middle ear?
questions.explanation:
The middle ear is not lined by keratinizing squamous epithelium, and hence its presence 
anywhere within the middle ear cleft is considered cholesteatoma. Various kinds of epithelia lining the middle ear are: • Ciliated columnar- around the eustachian tube opening (Protympanum) • Pavement like- attic/epitympanum • Cuboidal- rest

questions.question:
Question 2: Otoscopic image of a patient with a history of repeated middle ear infections is shown below. 
Which one of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

options.c: It is also known as epidermosis

questions.explanation:
128 
Sold by @itachibot The image shows the presence of a large mass of white keratin debris in the left upper quadrant of 
the left tympanic membrane. This along with clinical scenario is suggestive of 
cholesteatoma which is also known as epidermosis or keratoma Cholesteatoma is the presence of stratified squamous epithelium in middle ear where it is not 
usually present, i.e., skin in wrong place. A central white mass, consisting of keratin debris is produced by the matrix. For this reason, it 
has also been named epidermosis or keratoma. The term cholesteatoma is a misnomer because it neither contains cholesterol crystals nor it is a 
tumor to merit the suffix “oma.”

questions.question:
Question 3: 122 
Sold by @itachibot You see a patient with a history of painless foul-smelling ear discharge and loss of hearing for 
the past year. He had undergone tympanoplasty on the same ear 3 years back. What is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of secondary acquired cholesteatoma. The history 
of middle ear infection and hearing loss after surgery of the tympanic membrane makes the 
diagnosis more likely. Classification of cholesteatoma: 1. Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at 
birth. 2. Primary acquired cholesteatoma presents with no history of previous otitis media or a 
pre-existing perforation. It is associated with a defect in pars flaccida. 3. Secondary acquired cholesteatoma presents with a history of previous otitis media or a 
pre-existing perforation. It is associated with a defect in pars tensa.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following theories does not explain the origin of cholesteatoma?

options.b: Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
options.d: von Bekesy theory of mucosal metaplasia

questions.explanation:
von Békésy proposed the traveling wave theory, whereas Sade’s metaplasia theory explains the 
origin of cholesteatoma. Cholesteatoma can be of 2 main types: • Congenital cholesteatoma - explained by the presence of congenital cell rests within the middle 
ear and other parts of the temporal bone. • Acquired cholesteatoma - explained by a pathology either within the mastoid air cell system and 
eustachian tube drainage, or the tympanic membrane epithelium.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is the most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma?
questions.explanation:
The most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma is Habermann's theory. It proposes that 
the skin of the external auditory meatus grows or migrates into the middle ear through the 
posterosuperior marginal perforation or attic perforation forming cholesteatoma. 129 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most common site for primary cholesteatoma?
questions.explanation:
Prussak’s space is the most common site of primary cholesteatoma. It is the space in 
the epitympanum lying in between pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus.

questions.question:
Question 7: 123 
Sold by @itachibot An 8-year-old boy was referred to an otolaryngologist for subjective left-sided hearing loss. A 
hearing test revealed mild conductive hearing loss at low and middle frequencies. 
Otoendoscopy showed a mass with the appearance as shown below. Which of the following 
criteria is used to diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with the otoendoscopy showing a white pearly mass behind the intact 
eardrum in the anterosuperior quadrant is suggestive of congenital cholesteatoma. Levenson 
criteria should be satisfied in order to diagnose this condition. Levenson criteria: • A white mass behind the normal tympanic membrane • Normal pars tensa and pars flaccida • No prior history of otorrhoea • No prior history of otological procedure • Episodes of otitis media with effusion should not be considered as exclusion criteria. Another popular guideline used is Derlaki and Clemis which includes all the above except for the 
4th criteria.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following statements is false regarding the expansion of cholesteatoma and 
destruction of bone?

options.a: Release of enzymes like collagenase and acid phosphatase at the site of destruction
options.b: Destruction of bone mediated by pressure necrosis
options.c: Osteoclasts and mononuclear infiltrates play a role in bone destruction
options.d: Erosion of ossicles is more common in children compared to adults

questions.explanation:
Cholesteatoma does not cause bone destruction by pressure necrosis. Bone destruction by cholesteatoma has been attributed to enzymes liberated by osteoclasts and 
mononuclear inflammatory cells such as: • Collagenase • Acid phosphatase and • Proteolytic enzymes. Pediatric cholesteatoma (PC) has more inflammation and greater chances of ossicular erosion 
compared to adults. However, PC has lesser chances of petrous labyrinth invasion and lateral 
semicircular canal fistula formation.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient presented to your OPD for a second look surgery following a canal wall-up 
procedure for cholesteatoma removal. Where is the residual disease most likely to be seen? 124 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Residual cholesteatoma is most likely to be seen in the sinus tympani. 130 
Sold by @itachibot The involvement of sinus tympani, along with posterior mesotympanum, is a recognized risk 
factor for residual cholesteatoma. This is because it is particularly difficult to remove the disease 
from these areas. Canal wall-up procedures have a higher risk of leaving residual disease behind 
than the canal wall-down procedures. Sinus tympani or infra pyramidal recess is the medial of the two posterior spaces in the middle 
ear. It is bounded by: • Pyramid and vertical segment of facial nerve laterally • The stapes & oval window medially • Ponticulus superiorly • Subiculum inferiorly Image showing sinus tympani:

questions.question:
Question 10: Patients with tubotympanic type of chronic suppurative otitis media are considered safe 
compared to atticoantral disease. What is the reason?

options.a: Does not progress into malignancy usually
options.c: Does not involve the mastoid air cells

questions.explanation:
Tubotympanic type (TTD) of CSOM is considered the safe type in relativity to atticoantral disease 
(AAD) as TTD has less chance of complications than AAD. Note: TTD can also lead to complications but the incidence is much less than that in AAD.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following best describes the given otoscopy finding in a child with poor 
scholastic performance?
questions.explanation:
The given otoscopic image shows a subtotal perforation. It involves all four quadrants of the 
tympanic membrane but is covered by remnant pars tensa/annulus all around. 131 
Sold by @itachibot Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is the single most important cause of hearing 
impairment in rural populations. Children with CSOM have poor academic performance.

questions.question:
Question 12: A young adult presents with intermittent non-foul smelling mucoid discharge from the left 
ear for the past few years. Otologic examination revealed a central perforation of the 
tympanic membrane. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition?

options.a: No evidence of bone destruction in CT scans
options.b: Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infections are seen
options.c: Aural polyp if present, should never be avulsed

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario of intermittent mucoid discharge and central perforation of the tympanic 
membrane points to a diagnosis of tubotympanic type of CSOM, which is not associated with 
cholesteatoma. Atticoantral type is associated with cholesteatoma and it leads to dangerous 
complications due to its bone-eroding properties. Etiology of tubotympanic (benign or safe) type of CSOM: • As a sequela of acute otitis media • Ascending infection via the eustachian tube • Allergic conditions Bone destruction is not present in this type. Culture reveals mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection. Aural polyp if present should be removed and not avulsed before starting local treatment. This is 
due to the fact that the polyp may be arising from the stapes, facial nerve, or horizontal canal and 
its avulsion can lead to facial paralysis or labyrinthitis.

questions.question:
Question 13: A known case of tubotympanic disease was taken up for surgery and on examining the middle 
ear, few chalky white deposits were found between the ossicles. What is the diagnosis?

options.d: Candidal infection of the middle ear

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tympanosclerosis. It is a sequela of long-standing 
middle ear disease where there are hyaline deposits within the middle ear, which calcify leading to 
impaired mobility of ossicles. The common sites are the tympanic membrane, promontory, ossicles, joints, tendons, and oval 
and round windows. When hyalinization and calcification involve only the tympanic membrane, it is known as 
myringosclerosis.

questions.question:
Question 14: A first-year ENT postgraduate sees a child with permanent perforation of the tympanic 
membrane. Which of the following is a feature of such perforation?

options.a: It is seen in acute suppurative otitis media
options.b: It is caused by necrotizing otitis externa
options.c: It has squamous epithelium at its edges
options.d: Medical management can be tried initially

questions.explanation:
A permanent perforation is lined by squamous epithelium at its edges, hindering spontaneous 
healing. Features of a permanent perforation: • Seen in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) • Is similar to an epithelial lined fistulous tract • Cannot be medically managed, thus mandating surgery 132 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A young adult presents with a 3-year history of intermittent ear discharge. He complains of 
poor hearing, which improves during discharge periods, but is worse when the ear is dry. 
Which of the following explains this phenomenon? 126 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario describes the round window-shielding effect that is seen in tubotympanic type 
of CSOM. The round window-shielding effect is where the ear discharge shields the round window from 
sound waves. During the inactive phase (no discharge), the sound strikes both the oval window 
and round window together and the noise cancels itself out. So, the hearing is worse when the ear 
is dry. Cholesteatoma hearer is a patient with a discontinuous ossicular chain but the sound is conducted 
through the cholesteatoma to the footplate. On removing the cholesteatoma by surgery, the 
patient has worse hearing.

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient with chronic suppurative otitis media is posted for surgery. Preoperatively, the 
surgeon wants to assess the status of the ossicles so that he can be prepared for ossicular 
construction if required. Which of the following tests is useful here?
questions.explanation:
The patch test is useful in assessing the status of the ossicles preoperatively so that the surgeon 
can be prepared for ossicular reconstruction if required. It is done in tubotympanic type of CSOM. A thin paper-like cigarette foil is soaked in vaseline and cut into the size of perforation and is used 
to close the perforation. Pure tone audiometry is done before and after the closure of perforation. 
Results are as follows: • Improved hearing – intact ossicular chain • Decreased hearing – ossicular fixity or discontinuity • No improvement – technical fault or improper hearing. Another test done in the tubotympanic type of CSOM is Bonsin's test. When the eardrum is 
painted with 1 in 20% solution of silver nitrate, the perforation stands out as a black spot against 
a white background. Option A: Nine-step test is used to predict the ears at risk of middle ear barotrauma. Options B and D: The side-step test and Unterberger test are vestibular tests and are positive in 
perilymphatic fistula.

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following is true regarding the tubotympanic type of chronic suppurative otitis 
media?

options.a: Central perforation in antero-inferior quadrant is commonly seen
options.b: Blood stained ear discharge is seen
options.c: The discharge is scanty, purulent and foul smelling

questions.explanation:
Central perforation in the antero-inferior quadrant of tympanic membrane is commonly seen 
in tubotympanic type, while marginal perforation in the postero-superior quadrant is commonly 
seen in atticoantral type of CSOM. Bloody, scant, foul-smelling ear discharge, ear pain, hearing loss, and tinnitus are often seen in 
the atticoantral type of CSOM. 133 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is true about the atticoantral type of chronic suppurative otitis media?
questions.explanation:
Atticoantral type also called unsafe or dangerous type involves perforation of Shrapnell's 
membrane or pars flaccida (attic perforation). The disease is often associated with a bone-eroding process such as cholesteatoma, granulations, 
or osteitis. The risk of complications is high in this variety. 134 
Sold by @itachibot CSOM - Treatment and Complications
